body: Have you tried rescanning on the source side (i.e. not the device whose logs you posted, but the device it was trying to fetch the symlink from)?

@canton7: Yes. The rescan completes suspiciously quickly (within ten seconds), and it makes absolutely no difference: the desktop (the device on which the errors are appearing) still reports the same "incompatible symlink entry" error.

I have the same error.

```
[*****] 22:07:34 INFO: Puller (folder "Sync", dir "TMP/krautleaks reste/fäden/kc-b-2479161/*****.net/thumbnails/1293714318003.png"): incompatible symlink entry; rescan with newer Syncthing on source
imac:~ davidak$ file Sync/TMP/krautleaks\ reste/fäden/kc-b-2479161/*****.net/thumbnails/1293714228003.jpg
Sync/TMP/krautleaks reste/fäden/kc-b-2479161/*****.net/thumbnails/1293714228003.jpg: JPEG image data, JFIF standard 1.01
```

The files are actually files and no symlinks.

Same error here. Syncing between linux and freebsd.
Rescanning and restarting on both sides doesn't help.
It's pretty random - a video file symlink works but the subtitle file doesn't, both files work for another video/subtitle pair in the same directory, both fail for yet another pair.

This'll happen when there is a symlink that wasn't synced before the upgrade. A symlink doesn't have a modification time on it's own, so forcing a rescan of it is somewhat tricky. My best suggestion is to remove it, let Syncthing realize it's gone, then recreate it.

@calmh: Found the symlink in question - for some reason I had a symlink called ``music`` which led to ``/home/user/music`` but only on the server, not the desktop - and deleted it. Rescanned on the server, restarted the daemon on the desktop, and boom: no more errors.

I didn't bother recreating the symlink, because it served no purpose and shouldn't have even been there.

Happy to mark this as resolved and close from my perspective, but perhaps it's best to keep it open to see if @davidak, @kaey, and @bradbulger can resolve their issues with the same fix.

Oh, and here's a handy-dandy way of finding all the symlinks recursively from the current directory: ``ls -lR ./ | grep ^l``.

I ran into this as well, but with existing symlinks (not just new ones as @calmh described). I upgraded one machine (the always-on server) to 0.14.14 and booted up my desktop machine to upgrade it. I have syncthing set to launch on login and started getting notices of files deleted. Thinking this odd as I hadn't deleted anything since the machines were connected last, I stopped syncthing and upgraded to 0.14.14. Now I was seeing reports (like above) of invalid symlinks (even though they were present on the server side).

Cut to 12+ hours later, and I am in front of my laptop that is part of the sync group, disabling syncthing before allowing it to connect to the internet. I have 83 symlinks in the synced directory. Checking on the desktop, I have zero. Syncthing had removed all the symlinks on the desktop.

As a recovery measure,  I tarballed up all the symlinks on the laptop before upgrading and letting it sync, then manually removed the symlinks on the server (where they were still present) and restored the tarball and now the 3 machines all show as "Up to date" and have their 83 symlinks.

Some things I have noted about the symlinks:
- some were dangling symlinks to either files or directories
- some were to valid files or directories
- some were relative, some were full-path
- age of the symlink seems to have nothing to do with which ones were listed as failed
- only some of the list (53 iirc) were shown as "Failed" in the syncthing UI despite none of them being synchronized.
- all had been synchronized prior to the upgrade, none were "new" to be synced

I still have one further machine (another laptop) which needs to be updated to 0.14.14, and I am wondering if it will cause me trouble. Will actually hold off on booting and updating it now in case I can test something for @calmh, but a bit concerned that a "fix" introduced a (if not for the gtk gui) quiet data-loss in my environment. Fortunately I had a way to recover, but seems like the upgrade needed more safety code added to either cause syncthing to stop on boot, or fail to sync rather than wiping out data.

I removed the offending links on the master and left it for the rest of that day. It cleared on all syncing systems. I've been adding them back on the master now, and so far it seems to be syncing them successfully.

I confirm the problem described by @javamorin In my situation there was three machines, one with 0.14.13 and two upgraded to 0.14.14. 
All of the symlinks were suddenly deleted. I had about 8 hundred of symlinks (I like symlinks). Thank God I had another computer offline and managed to restore the symlinks (and before that I went back to 0.14.13 on all of the machines). I think that using 0.14.14 is _very dangerous_ for symlinks fans. I will wait for 0.14.15.

All of my systems are 32bit linux.

rename.from: "Incompatible Symlink Entry" errors between two 0.14.14 installations

body: What's the OS type on these symlinks-deleted boxes?
Mine OS type is linux, 32 bit.

- source - docker ubuntu 16.04
- comp1 - linux mint
- comp2 - linux mint

updated source from 0.14.13 to 0.14.14 
updated comp1 from 0.14.13 to 0.14.14; noticed exclamation point between source and comp1 due to symlinks
fixed all symlinks by deleting on source and comp1
created new symlinks on comp1
source and comp1 in sync

brought up comp2 running 0.14.13 (was offline during source and comp1 upgrade)
updated comp2 to 0.14.14
noticed most symlinks got deleted; one symlink left but marked in conflict
deleted conflicting symlink on comp1, comp2 and source
recreated all symlinks again; this was done on comp1

all in sync between the source; comp1 and comp2
back in business
@calmh Linux / 64bit (Arch Linux to be specific) on all machines.
